Recently, a friend of mine had a birthday. She has a love of all things vintage, including pacman. As such, I wanted to make her a set of 8 bit cookie cutters.

Paulforest's ( http://www.thingiverse.com/PaulForest ) offerings are cool (although not 8 bit), and the tool he used to create them is fantastic. Unfortunately, it doesn't offer the ability to create multiple levels. I wanted to include the features of each of the ghosts.


So here they are, Pacman, Blinky, Pinky, Inky and Clyde all in lovely 8 bit form.

Print, Cut, Bake, Eat

With Christmas quickly approaching, I recommend gingerbread

I needed something to hold the battery wires out of the way from the props, and a holder for the antenna wires. So designed this.
It is designed to go on the top plate, using the 2 original back screws to hold it in place. I have made it so you can run the xt60 connector through it. I also drilled out the back hole in my top plate to take an antenna sma connector.
The antenna holder is designed for 3.2mm antenna tubes, and i also made a channel from the underside to the antenna tubes which will enable you to run the antenna wires through the back slots in the top plate right into the antenna tubes.

A physically instructive toy.

Heavily inspired by Lego Ninjago Airjitzu toys and Beyblade (all trademarks are the property of their respective owners).

The spinning top consists of 4 parts. The axis with the gear is compatible with the Lego Ninjago Airjitzu toys. The disk consists of two identical halves that allow you to insert up to 6 coins (5 Euro-cent) for more momentum. The bottom cone should fit tightly on the axis, but could also be screwed on with a M3x30 screw or you could just use glue.

Warning: If you put in some coins you might want to be careful near valuable furniture!

The launcher consists of a box with handle and lid and the starter strip.

As an arena we used a lid from a big pot, turned upside down and placed on a bowl for stability, but of course you can use whatever you want.

The gear was created with the library by GregFrost: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575

Have fun!

Videos:
https://youtu.be/4WPKlNJpLWA
https://youtu.be/g8MgX2UFUk8

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm per layer

Infill:

10 %

Notes:

The gear and starter strip are the crucial parts. If their teeth come out fine the rest shouldn't be difficult. With the standard printing speed the teeth were truncated, but with half the normal speed they turned out nicely.

For the starter strip the shell thickness should be reduced to 0.4 mm (one nozzle size). For all other pieces 0.8 mm would be fine.

The laucher box is easy to print, but if the axis doesn't turn easily in the hole, then you could use a file to widen the hole a bit, or you can adjust the parameter "gearHoleR" in the "spinning_top.scad" file.

Also be aware that different printers and different materials have direct impact on sizes.
(I've used PLA.)

title: remixed Roter Sand Lighthouse
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
We have devided the part A, B, F and G of the beautiful Roter Sand lighthouse from josemivaz to match the printer bed of a Prusa i3. This parts need to be glued together.

We made two different versions of part A and B:

  1. without _fixable:
    These files don't have any option to mount them on the ground

  2. with the _fixable in their filename:
    These files contain an attachment which is invisible from the outside. It allows you to mount the lighthouse on the floor with M8 screws. We made them to use the lighthouse outside to prevent them from beeing stolen or fail over by the wind.

All other parts can be used are original and should be used from josemivaz:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1009560

We have used 3D Builder from Microsoft and slic3r.

Draft could be usefull to prevent warping.

Note: The objects are huge. It takes some time to print them!

description.text:
This scad adds a greg-style support shelf to the edge of the turret piece to allow for the required overhang with no other support material.
Note that this thing will likely become obsolete when (if?) 3dYeti updates his (awesome) design.

Enter your layer height into the scad, compile, export and print. Snap the support piece off after the print.
Or you can download the pre-made one, it's compiled for a layer height of 0.3mm. It may work for you, run it through your skeining tool and make sure there's one layer going across to the support structure to hold up the rest of the print.

description.text:
Because the stand http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1323186 was too skew and the stand http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1387000 does not fit for my charger coil ( https://www.amazon.com/Anker-Wireless-PowerPort-Charging-Qi-Enabled/dp/B00Y839YMU ) and the Galaxy S7 edge I designed my own version from scratch with FreeCAD. It looks similar to the both others at the first view but meets better my requirements.

Edit 2016/09/13: Added model "Charging_Stand_Hardcase" without the phone holder lip. This model is recommended if you are using a hardcover for your phone which is a little bit thicker than the space between the cradles body and lip of the original model.

Edit 2016/12/17: Uploaded FreeCAD-Drawing on request

Edit 2017/08/08: Upladed V2 of both versions with covered lead through for USB-plug. Looks better when the phone is not in the stand.

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 Horizontal LCD Mounting Bracket

title: Prusa i3 Horizontal LCD Mounting Bracket Version 2

description.text:
This is a variant of the Prusa i3 Horizontal LCD holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:139016) which is installed on the very top of the printer. The LCD display (from RepRap Discount) is installed horizontally leaving free the top of the printer. It can be installed either on the left or the right. One of the LCD holders has a slot for the SD-card. You will need:
  • 1 x 24 cm (9"1/2) 8 mm or 5/16" threaded rod
  • 6 x 8 mm or 5/16" nuts
  • 5 x M3 (4-40) x 2 cm (3/4") bolts
  • 5 x M3 (4-40) nuts
  • 2 x M3 or (4-40) washers
  • The plastic parts
  • a zip tie (optional)
    • Mount it as shown on the pictures. A zip tie is installed to prevent the LCD from vibrating. You do not need to drill holes in the frame to install this holder. It might be Sgraber's frame compatible. If you have issues, please, contact me. Use support material to print it.

author: ctheroux

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/85Cubrkmuxl

title: FT (Flite Test) Mighty Mini Arrow Center Pod and Hatch Cover

description.text:
A 3D-printable version of the center pod and hatch cover for the Mini Arrow by Flite Test:
http://store.flitetest.com/ft-mighty-mini-arrow/

You will want to print the center pod with only one or two shells and 10% fill, otherwise it will be stupidly heavy. The benefit of using the printed version is that it has thinner walls than the foam version, thus allowing the use of a wider battery (up to 35mm) without having to redesign the rest of the plane. The back side of the pod has a standard internal width to accept the stock power pod. It also has two small knobs that not only act as friction points for the foam pod, but they are also placed to lock into the printable power pods by AustinSaintAubin found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1096211

The hatch cover is intended to be printed in something flexible and hot-glued in place like the original. It wraps around under the plane as a mini skid guard. It can be secured at the back of the plane with Velcro as it overlaps the top of the canopy by about an inch, or you can simply tape it closed.

Please note, the stock foam hatch cover should still work if you prefer it.

This is a hamster ladder for its habitat. I have designed in such a way that you can print it in parts on a smaller printer. You can print the midsection multiple times and one end section then use the plugs and some glue to put it all together. Maybe print it in wood filament PLA for that wood look ? :)

IMPORTANT

After glueing DO NOT put it in your hamster's habitat UNTIL the glue fumes are long gone. The fumes can severely hurt your furry pal! Also print this in PLA as the gasses given off by ABS are toxic! Print at your own risk!

title: reprap cube - speed optimized, big built aerea, replicating

description.text:
This in another reprap derivat printer. The main idea to built it was to get a printer which is fast and has lots of space to build things. The x and y axis work with an etch-a-sketch kind of mechanism with two belts. The z axis is driven by 3 thread rods. The main frame is a cube built of 20mm extruded aluminium profile. my frame is 400x400x400 but this can be scaled as you like.
The extruder i designed for the printer is that one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14311 and the electronics i use are these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6480
The pulleys were rendere with the scad script by droftarts: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627 thanks a lot for that. Except for the frame,the rods and some standard parts, all parts are printed. (The edge-connecters could be printed too, this can be extended here)
UPDATE: i connected the stepper drivers and the other electronix for the axis today and did some first axis-tests. There is a video on vimeo:
https://vimeo.com/50614766 and another one where also the z-axis is moving every few seconds after a layer is finished (it is printing the squirrel thing with honeycomb infill)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=989PFsqJshA
I had it running without an extruder just to test if the axis go as fast as i want them to run (which they do). For printing i think the speed will have to be reduced. Next thin will be the endstops, and finally the extruder.

title: the colonies (scenario for seafarers)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing contains all parts for the scenario "the colonies" for the settler basic game I already made (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1238980) and the seafarers expansion (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1393862). You need both games to play this scenario!

for the roules check out here (https://kelvsyc.wordpress.com/catan-scenario-and-variant-guide/ or in the pdf-files (check under thing files).

These are the pieces you need to print. Choose yourself which individual tile-designs you prefere for the game:

  • Tiles (landscapes): 3 x landscapes sea, 3 x landscapes jungle, 2 x lanscapes volcano, 1 x landscape gold
  • 92 x colonie-tokens: 24 x discovery tokens (jungle, symbol: palm), 22 x gold tokens (gold river, symbol: crown), 22 x ore tokens (mountains, symbol: mountain), 24 x gem tokens (desert, symbol: gem)
  • 20 x exploration camps ("bases", 5 per player)
  • 4 x war fleets (flotilla, one per player)
  • 1 x pirate ship
  • 1 x set of number tokens (4,5,6,10,3,9). The number tokens are placed on the landscapes showing the same numbers (volcano, jungle and gold river)
  • 12 x ships (3 per player)
  • 1 x dice

Like for other expansions and scenarios, I had to do slight changes to the gameplay and material because of the 3d-design of the tiles.

The changes are the followings:

  • the bases are placed at the sides of newly discovered landscapes instead than on the tiles themself. The bases should be placed on the tile-sides that point seawards. If thats not possible, the base should be turned in a way that the lighthouse is near the tile you discovered. So there are no missunderstandings when a base is placed between two tiles.
  • the colonie-tokens can be stacked under the settlements (max 3). For transporting them with your ships, stacke them under the ship and move everything together (ship and tokens).
  • When you discover a new landscape, roll the colonie-dice to determine what kind of landscape you discovered. The symbols on the dice are the folowing: sheep = wool, crown = gold river, waves = sea, volcano = volcano, mountain = mountain, dead fish = desert. If the dice shows a type of landscape that is not available anymore, just roll the dice again until it shows a landscape that is available.

OTHER SCENARIOS & VARIANTS: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1410173

Big thx to all the designers that helped me to build this expansion with their superbe work

Printer:

Prusa i3 (hephestos)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

1 mm

Infill:

10-30%

Notes:

Print the bases with support from the printing-table.

*Update after using it for a while I added a shorter version. The taller version blocks the top half of the tach depending on how your seat is adjusted.

Shroud for Jeasun HUD X5 to block glare from display while driving at night.
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01AJQ4VVI

HUD fits into shroud snug; depress rocking switch to install.
Hole in bottom of design is for easier removal.

Installed on a 2015 Honda Fit.

Cable routing instructions:
Pop the speaker out feed cable through from under the dash.
Attach a zip tie a few inches from the end of the cable.
Fold the end of the zip tie over and feed back under the dash until the end of the folded zip ties protrudes. Grab with needle nose pilers. you will need to push and pull to get the cable routed. Don't force it take your time.
go back under the dash and route cable above the steering wheel adjustment
zip tie to other wiring harnesses to keep cable away from pedals but leave slack on both ends for adjustment and to be able to unplug from you obd 2 port.

xzy da vinci 1.0

Any

Notes:

walls are 2mm thick all around, should be easy to print 100% solid on printers with a 0.4mm nozzle DIA.

use a filament that can handle the heat your dash will see in the summer!

use a bridge over cable and switch holes no supports needed

description.text:
I'am currently building a forced air solar thermal collector and here in Germany you can get HT-pipe (waste water pipe) really cheap so I thought, time for some unintended use as an air duct.

I will be using an old 80mm fan I scavenged from an old PC-PSU to create the needed flow of about 50m³/h. Since I did not want to use hot glue or duct tape (although this would have been the use case duct tape was designed for) to connect the fan to the duct work, I decided to make the fan part of a pipe. Just like you got powered mine cart tracks in Minecraft I now got a powered HT-Pipe :D

You will need the following:
-80mm fan
-4xM3 nuts
-4xM3*35mm Bolts
-optional: 4xM3 washers
-one 75mm lip-seal (as seen on the pictures)

title: Support for electric bed remote control - ProMotion

description.text:
The wired remove control of my electric bed was physically broken.
I created this model to replace the original broken part.
It can be screwed in place of the broken piece and works the same way.

La télécommande filiaire de mon lit électrique s'est cassée.
J'ai créé ce modèle afin de pouvoir remplacer la partie endommagée.
Ce modèle peut se visser en remplacement de la pièce d'origine et assure les mêmes fonctions.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

16.7%

Notes:

Depending on your printer and material.
You can print it the way it is in the STL but then you'll need a big support and layers are on the weak side, but it allows to have a better precision for the hooking cylinders.
You can also rotate the model in order to minimize support's need, but I had some trouble with the precision of cylinder build "on support".

Tout dépend de l'imprimante et du matériel.
Il est possible d'imprimer tel que présenté dans le modèle mais cela nécessite un grand support et place les lignes les plus fragiles sur les endroits où il y a des contraintes, cependant les cylindres d’emboîtements seront plus précis.
L'alternative est de tourner la pièce, cela nécessite moins de support et permet une plus grande solidité; cependant la précision des emboîtements sera réduite.

title: Ink Stamp with switchable stamp plate

description.text: This ink stamp has a modular design to allow you to switch the stamp end. The stamp plate uses a dovetail joint to hold it in place. This way, you only need to print one stamp handle. this design also allows you to print with the business end of the stamp plate facing up.

Print out the Stl and assemble with one m4 flat head bolt shorter than 40mm. of course, you probably want to change the wording on the stamp itself, so go and edit the skp file and export your own stls.
Oh, and as qharley noted, you'll need to mirror image the text (unless your making a "redrum" stamp).

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/g3H6Nbf8GGm

After building this awesome GP bird, I found it to be nose heavy, and not wanting to add sticky leads to the thin surfaces of the wing. I decided to crate a "lead" compartment.
It is attached by 3M double side foamed sticky tape (common servo tape in RC), and filled with sinkers leads from my tackle box.
you can add and remove from it.
Note: since I am not fully convinced on the 3M tape for this use, I added Duck tape (Red to match).
more than 50 flights on 10-20 MPH winds and still solid.
Added bonus, it doubles as landing skid on the back.

3D printable model of Lili from Tekken.
I have uploaded 3 models, one with chains, without and one flipped. The flipped one is probably the easiest one to print. I recommend using Brim and Support Type Touching buildplate if you print that one.
Downscaling might destroy the layers, so be careful with that.

For the other two non-flipped models I recommend printing with support settings in Cura, my recommendation:
Support; everwhere, overhang angle degree: 40 , fill amount: around 11-15 (lower is easier to peel off).
I also recommend using Brim settings activated to make the support strucutre stable.
Alternatively you can generate own support structure in Meshmixer.

I recommend using Kapton tape or similar to make things easier with support structure.

description.text:
These are 5mm LED difffusers for small LED grids. They fit 5mm LEDs loosely, and are good for LEDs in a breadboard.

Grid sizes uploaded:
1x1
1x2
1x3
1x4
1x5
2x2

You can easily make your own custom sizes by importing the 1x1 diffuser into a design program and duplicating it. Then you can arrange them as you like.

I used this on a 3x3 LED grid on a breadboard to make a tic tac toe game with the Raspberry Pi. For more info, see https://electrothoughts.wordpress.com/2016/03/07/tic-tac-toe-arcade-game-with-raspberry-pi/.

I recommend using Kapton tape or similar to make things easier with support structure.

description.text:
Saw a few Dragon fly's on here but none really to my liking as I had to get mine out fast, for a mothers day present.

Printed really well despite there being way too many errors in the stl file, but it printed fine at 100% scale.

One-piece print with supports touching the base, the legs are delicate,
I ran this at 60mm/s, with a 'tweak' at 15mm to slow the print speed right down (40-50%)
so it can print the legs correctly.
I had to superglue a spring in as I snapped one off during de-support, sad face.

Printer:

Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Print wings down! (legs up)

Slow the print speed DOWN after 15mm.

For the body, I created a loft with two open profiles and 5 open loop guide curves, this gave me 1/4 of the model, mirrored in x and y & offset to create 3 more lofts which were then merged, gaps all over the place, but that's how I wanted my dragon fly's body to look with the spikes at the end, this gave rise to all the errors and knit surface just wan't happening.

Wings were boss extrudes with extruded spline cuts, mirrored in x.

The Eyes are 2 separate revolves.

The Legs are 2.5mm circles perpendicular (top and right plane respectively) with connecting 3D sketches, first time I've used these for a physical print / model.
They weren't too bad once the angles were neat.(this took the most time)
3 legs are then mirrored in x.

author: WattsForLunch

description.text:
Simple Robocode Robot Explanation Model for Programming Lectures

License: CC-by-SA (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/)

From http://robocode.sourceforge.net/ :
"Robocode is an Open Source programming game, where the goal is to develop
a robot battle tank to battle against other tanks in Java or .NET.
The robot battles are running in real-time and on-screen."

This model loosely resembles the robots shown in the graphical arena of Robocode,
and can be used to show the robots movement and rotation capabilities.

We assume the robot in the game is 40x40x40 units (mm). You may want to upscale the
STL files before printing the model, for example by 2 to get a 8x8x8 cm³ object, which is
printable without support on most printers (you may have to rotate some of the pieces
accordingly).

Customizing with OpenSCAD: Because of using OpenSCADs minkowski() function
in order to get a smooth finish with no sharp edges, rendering takes a lot of CPU
time for higher $fn resolutions.

title: Dwarfclan War Hero (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This model was designed to go along with Blackschmoll's fantastic Dwarf Army and for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for Wayfarer Tactics. If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

description.text:
This is a project for a 5th grade earth science class. It will be their first experience with 3D printing and Tinkercad. I hope that I'll be able to turnkey it and lead the lesson with one class and the teacher, then have the teacher do the lesson with her other class. The procedure uses most of the important actions on Tinkercad other than lifting objects off the workplane - moving and resizing, holes (negative space), grouping, the adjust tool, etc.

This project uses overlapping cylinders for the layers of the earth. It could also be done using the Variable Tube shape generator to make shells, but I found the sliders for the parameters to be a bit too fiddle for the students to use accurately.
NGSS

This is a project for a 5th grade earth science class. It will be their first experience with 3D printing and Tinkercad. I hope that I'll be able to turnkey it and lead the lesson with one class and the teacher, then have the teacher do the lesson with her other class. The procedure uses most of the important actions on Tinkercad other than lifting objects off the workplane - moving and resizing, holes (negative space), grouping, the adjust tool, etc.
This project uses overlapping cylinders for the layers of the earth. It could also be done using the Variable Tube shape generator to make shells, but I found the sliders for the parameters to be a bit too fiddle for the students to use accurately

• Login to Tinkercad
    • Make and align the layers of the Earth
  • Drag a cylinder onto the workplane
  • Grab one of the corners of the cylinder and drag into to make the diameter 1 mm. Hold the shift key down while resizing to keep it round. Change the color to black. This is to mark the center of the earth and will be deleted later. Make the height of the cylinder 10 mm.
  • Drag another cylinder onto the workplane and resize it to diameter of 30 mm and a height of 5 mm. Color it red. This is the inner core. Don't worry about the position of the cylinders, we'll arrange them properly later.
  • Drag another cylinder onto the workplane and resize it to diameter 83 mm and a height of 4 mm. Color it orange. This is the outer core.
  • Drag another cylinder onto the workplane and resize it to diameter 150 mm and a height of 3 mm. Color it yellow. This is the mantle.
  • Click and drag a rectangle that touches all the cylinders to select them.

  • Use Adjust --> Align to align the cylinders in the X and Y directions.

    Cut a wedge out of the Earth

  • Drag a rectangle onto the workplane. Resize it so it completely covers the right half of the Earth. Click on Hole to make it negative space.
  • Use the Tilt control to rotate the rectangle 22.5 degrees clockwise. If you mess up the tilting use Undo and try again.
  • Drag another rectangle onto the workplane and resize so it completely covers the left half of the Earth. Click on Hole to make it negative space. Rotate it 22.5 degrees counterclockwise.
  • Move the negative space rotated rectangles into position so that the intersect at the center of the earth (use the black center cylinder as a guide). This should leave a 45 degree wedge uncovered.
  • When the negative space rectangles are in position select the black center cylinder and delete it.
  • Click and drag and drag a rectangle around all the pieces on the workplane. Click on Group to combine them. This should leave you with a wedge shaped model of the layers of the Earth. Group will change the color of the layers, if you want the original colors back click on Color and choose Multicolor.
    • Your model is now ready to download and print. Print in yellow, then color the inner and outer cores with a marker. Color the outer edge with a think border for the crust. Optional - add your initials by dragging letters onto the mantle. The letters are 4 mm high so they should stick out 1 mm above the mantle.

description.header: Project: 3D print the layers of the Earth
description.text:
Objective

Students will learn to use Tinkercad and make a scale model of the layers of the Earth

Audience

This is a lesson for a 5th grade science class

Preparation

This project will be part of a 5th grade earth science unit. This will be their first experience with Tinkercad, they will need to make accounts on Tinkercad first.

Scale Model

Scale Model - using a scale factor for 43 km = 1 mm. At this scale the crust is less than 1 mm and will be drawn on with marker rather than being modeled in 3D. This should drive home the idea of just how thin the Earth's crust really is.

Measurements are measured from the core, they are not thicknesses.

Inner Core - 1,300 km = 30 mm
Outer Core - 3,550 km = 83 mm
Mantle - 6,450 km = 150 mm
Crust - 6,550 km = 150 mm

Steps
  1. Login to Tinkercad

Make and align the layers of the Earth

  1. Drag a cylinder onto the workplane
  2. Grab one of the corners of the cylinder and drag into to make the diameter 1 mm. Hold the shift key down while resizing to keep it round. Change the color to black. This is to mark the center of the earth and will be deleted later. Make the height of the cylinder 10 mm.
  3. Drag another cylinder onto the workplane and resize it to diameter of 30 mm and a height of 5 mm. Color it red. This is the inner core. Don't worry about the position of the cylinders, we'll arrange them properly later.
  4. Drag another cylinder onto the workplane and resize it to diameter 83 mm and a height of 4 mm. Color it orange. This is the outer core.
  5. Drag another cylinder onto the workplane and resize it to diameter 150 mm and a height of 3 mm. Color it yellow. This is the mantle.
  6. Click and drag a rectangle that touches all the cylinders to select them.

  7. Use Adjust --> Align to align the cylinders in the X and Y directions.

    Cut a wedge out of the Earth

  8. Drag a rectangle onto the workplane. Resize it so it completely covers the right half of the Earth. Click on Hole to make it negative space.
  9. Use the Tilt control to rotate the rectangle 22.5 degrees clockwise. If you mess up the tilting use Undo and try again.
  10. Drag another rectangle onto the workplane and resize so it completely covers the left half of the Earth. Click on Hole to make it negative space. Rotate it 22.5 degrees counterclockwise.
  11. Move the negative space rotated rectangles into position so that the intersect at the center of the earth (use the black center cylinder as a guide). This should leave a 45 degree wedge uncovered.
  12. When the negative space rectangles are in position select the black center cylinder and delete it.
  13. Click and drag and drag a rectangle around all the pieces on the workplane. Click on Group to combine them. This should leave you with a wedge shaped model of the layers of the Earth. Group will change the color of the layers, if you want the original colors back click on Color and choose Multicolor.

Your model is now ready to download and print. Print in yellow, then color the inner and outer cores with a marker. Color the outer edge with a think border for the crust.

Optional - add your initials by dragging letters onto the mantle. The letters are 4 mm high so they should stick out 1 mm above the mantle.

Results

This project was completed with two 5th grade classes. Students were able to create a scale model cut out of the Earth in one class period. It was their first experience using Tinkercad.

The most common problem was not using the shift key when resizing the cylinders, so they ended up oval. The kids added their initials to the models, and I stuck some magnetic tape on the backs to make them into refrigerator magnets.

We like to display the holiday and thank you cards we received by standing them on shelves, desks and tables. The problem is every time you walk by, the slightest breeze topples them over, or cards with horizontal top folds end up doing the splits and looking silly. If you have the same problems, print a handful of these little card holders and put them to work. 
Each holder has two card slots, one strait and one slanted. The straight one work for cards that have a vertical fold or single page cards. The slanted slot is for cards with a horizontal top fold. Each slot has a small bump and divot in it to securely hold paper in a range of thicknesses. For those heavy or difficult to control cards, you can also use a small dab of tacky poster putty on the base to hold them securely to a surface.
They are also useful as place card or business card holders. So print a handful for yourself or give a bunch as gifts.

print_settings.Notes:: If I can get the code parameterized well enough, I'll put this model in the Customizer, though the current published render works as-is with various-sized buns.

description.text:
I started making my own hamburger buns a few months ago -- to great success. It's very easy to do and the benefits are pretty good: fresher, better taste, not mushy! The only part of the experience that was sub-par was the finished, sliced bun. I either sliced too high or too low, or, most often, some of each. My finished bun was cut almost as bad as the commercial buns. Most helpful hints in this area suggest using a cutting board as a guide. This proved to be awkward and impractical.

But hey! I've got a 3D printer and OpenSCAD.

Here's what I came up with, and it works remarkably well. My bun slicing guide is large enough to accommodate buns up to 4 1/2 inches in diameter. The slicing height is maxed at 3/4 inch (that's a 3/4-inch bottom) and is adjustable down to about about 1/4 inch, in 1/4 inch steps using the spacer disks. Just print the number of discs you think you need, but only 3 will fit under the gripper ribs. The gripper ribs keep the bun from spinning as you slice away at it. (which version 1 lacked and which turned out to be much needed.)

To use it, place any needed spacer disk on the cutting tray, put the bun in place and hold your knife flat against the two side rails and grip the guide's handle, keeping your fingers behind the guard and well away from the cutting path -- the knife edge will be passing through the back part of the guide (see the pic) and no one wants to have their day ruined. Just take your time and be aware of where the knife edge is at all times -- basic kitchen safety.

If you have an electric knife, use it for better quality cuts. If not, a bread knife will work almost as well, and its what I use when I don't want to be bothered getting out the electric knife.

One last key to making this work well -- put some rubber feet on the bottom (see pics). The added stability is worth the minor cost since it makes the guide much easier and safer to use.

Printing notes:
You will need to enable supports, but they're perpendicular to the two surfaces and those surfaces (where the knife blade goes) are going to be scratched by your knife blade, anyway.

Cooking note:
I started off with this excellent recipe from All Recipes: http://allrecipes.com/recipe/233652/homemade-hamburger-buns/ and have modified it slightly. Since I live a mile above sea level, minor adjustments - mostly to the process - were needed. I replaced 4 oz of AP flour with bread flour to help the structure and I bake for 18-20 minutes at 350 instead of 15 minutes at 375. Non-altitude-related changes: I use a bread machine to make the dough. I portion and freeze the dough balls before the first rise and use them one-at-a-time, as needed. I don't use the egg wash, but a light mist of milk right before baking makes a nicely-browned top.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium works well

Infill:

20% is fine

Notes:

PLA or ABS - either is fine.

This print covers a fair amount of surface area and will not fit on many of the smaller printer beds. I'm sorry about that -- can't be helped. I understand the frustration well, having started this hobby with a plywood Printrbot Simple. I could make a smaller version of the slicing guide -- perhaps for slider-sized buns -- if there is a need. My model is in OpenSCAD and is almost completely parameterized, though I haven't test-dropped the diameter down that far. Those silly-but-needed ribs on the inside curve add almost an hour to the rib-less,5-second, full render in OpenSCAD. I'll see if I can figure a way to optimize the code.

If I can get the code parameterized well enough, I'll put this model in the Customizer, though the current published render works as-is with various-sized buns.

description.text:
This is a launch-able 3-D printed rocket. I made this because I wanted to design my own rocket that could actually launch! Print each piece and then epoxy each piece together. In order to launch, glue a shock cord to the inside of the body tube and tie it to the slot in the nose cone and tie the parachute to the nose cone as well. Next, pack some flame-retardant paper into the rocket and insert the parachute into the rocket. I recommend using a A8-3 Estes Engine for the first flight. This rocket can withstand all the way up to a C6-5 Estes engine without losing control. With a A8-3 the rocket will go about 600 feet and with a C6-5 the rocket will get close to 1000 feet high. Once retrieved the rocket can be reused over and over. This rocket is made for a 1/8" launch lug to launch it in a straight line. Feel free to comment and ask any questions in regard to the rocket. Thanks, I hope you enjoy.

3/11/16
Files updated and better oriented for better print.

3/29/16
Added a file of the nosecone cut in half. This nosecone will be easier to print and be stronger.

Check back soon for more updates!

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 PLA Model

Resolution:

≤ 200 microns

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Use supports on the nosecone unless you want to make the nosecone flat.

Launch-able 3-D Printed Rocket

I would love if someone could make edits or tell me how this ended up. I have no access to a 3D printer but would love if someone could print this out for me. All the 3D companies' websites I have visited priced the rocket too high. This might be a scaling issue (see above). If interested in printing me a copy e-mail me at [email protected] please.

Thanks,
Kyle

This is a "car" created with a 3-d printer in order to fullfil the objective of a prechallenge of my university group "UC3M Challenge - Mission: MARS".
The prechallenge consist in making a "car" with the 3-d printer that is going to race in a 5 degree inclination ramp which is made of sandpaper.

I have used the marbel caster created by HipsterLogic, you can see it at the following adress: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8959
I only change the ball diameter by 17mm instead of 16.5mm in order to allow the marbel rotate freely.
The other part of the "car" is a difference of cylinders which I design with openscad. This is not design in the best position for printing it. I complile the file with "replicatorg", and this program have a function that allow you to change the orientation of the element we are going to print. The one I used is the "mirror" reflecting in the z-axis.
Onde I had all the pieces printed, I glued the parts using a hot melt glue gun.
Hope you like it :)

Crash harder, fly faster with a 30 degree angle and capture all of it with a RunCame2. Straps should fit either front or back and allows room for most antennas behind the mount plate. I left a little extra room on the sides so it wasn't a super tight fit, but don't have a RunCam to test it out. Allen screws are accessible underneath the plate by moving plate to the side during install. If anyone has any tweaks, requests or the RunCam2 just doesn't fit let me know Enjoy!

The house is printed bottom down. The roof is printed standing at the side. With support, because the internal beam stops 5mm from the print bed. The support area is very small.

description.text:
Everyone playing with small computers like Arduino's knows you need a 5V power input for your device to work. Using a higher voltage meens you need a voltage regulator, like a 7805 or something, but that gives heat and consumes power by itself.

Using 7.2V is the best you can do, because 7.2 volts in combination with a voltage regulator like the 7805 leaves you 5V exactly, with a minimum of heat generation.

The Canon LP-E6 is worlds most sold battery and is extremely cheap to buy, if you buy a non branded version. This is a 7.2 volt battery, so now you only need a battery plate, like this one.

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0 Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Because the plate and the spacers are printed separate you don't need any kind of support.

After printing you have to make the contacts for the battery.
The holes are allready there, you only have to place some sheetmetal of contact blades in the holes and connect your wires to them.

For the blades, I use this pinball switch blades, because I happen to have them laying around a lot :-)
http://www.marcospecialties.com/pinball-parts/06-8AS-20

Maybe some sanding is needed. This depends on the quality of your printer.

I used 123D design to design this part.

On request the RAW files are available.

Have fun with it

After I have made to working models, I removed the Work in Progress mark for this item.

I like it if you leave a comment or list your print under "Make", so I can see you liked it.

The Spector Gadget Multi Holder is an attachment for the Python Prosthetic hand by Aaron Brown of Axislab 3D. You can find this hand at:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/python-utility-hand-alternative-assistive-device

The idea was to use two child locks you can find in most stores (I bought these at a 99 cent store). They would probably work better for smaller objects if you could cut more teeth into them. They are meant to be super glued into place. (You might be able to get away with drilling a small hole from the side and putting a screw in to hold them, but I am afraid that could interfere with the spring/button mechanism.)

I would print the main and attach parts with supports. The knob part is best to print separately so that the threads come out right. Suggest printing at 0.2 mm layer height and 50% infill.

The FreeCAD files are included. Please feel free to modify and share this design.

Version 2 was not printed, it is the CAD picture. It was changed so that the distance between the locks is shorter (total length of the holder is now 120 mm). I also added another threaded block to the bottom of the attachment block to provide more strength to the assembly.

remixed_from.author: JAP
remixed_from.title: High quality nose pliers (Pinzas de punta)

description.text:
This is a mod of Jap's High Quality Nose Pliers. I really liked the design but they werent as tough as i wanted. I modified them:

  • Shrank the snap down slightly so the 2 halves would fit together without breaking.

  • made the handles fatter with a truss structure inside so they wont bend.

  • Braced the jaws so they are stronger.

  • Increased the size of the central joint.

  • Put a wide gripping area in the jaw for bigger objects.
    • Of course, they arent as strong as steel pliers, but they should be good for light duty use. I wanted them for handling fragile things made of plastic or wood.

Snap together with a vise. If the fit is too tight you can scale one of the halves to make it fit better. Scale the socket side up or the plug side down. 1 percent increments should be good. I did most of the work is tinkercad. I changed the size of the hole in the socket side and the plug using Blender. I usually print this at 150% on my Afinia https://tinkercad.com/things/liwmEolxJyJ-workspace/edit

Szyna

One of the last extension libraries I wrote in OpenScad had to do with height maps. This thing implements height maps in Banate CAD. You can read the blog entry here: http://williamaadams.wordpress.com/2011/11/25/and-height-maps-for-all/ It's fairly straight forward in Banate CAD to do a height map from any image. It's actually the ImageSampler object that has the capability. You can then add this to this other object called a RubberSheet, and away you go! You can also specify a thickness, so it's not just a surface, it's actually a solid. The image with the purplish background is the generated mesh loaded into MeshLab. MeshLab was kind enough to remove the duplicate vertices for me. I'll have to do that within Banate CAD itself some day.

1) Download image
2) Print
3) Rejoice! For the adventurous, go download Banate CAD, and get the .fab file, and start playing around with things. The blog entry might give you some hints and ideas.

description.text: My first attempt at 3D designs, following a full size BB8 build I thought I'd tackle R2D2. Here's a full size Dome (Work in progress). The lower and upper rings have holes for alignment which 1.75 filament can be used in on the edge to edge gaps. Top pie pieces have removable supports. All is designed for ABS to minimise shrinkage and warping. 28/5 added a board bracket (to be glued inside the dome), fits a Ardunio and an adafruit 16 channel servo controller along with a 12v - 5v dc convertor (the one's used in cars) as I'm using a 11.1v lipo battery. Video of completed dome.. https://youtu.be/46cj6XR9Y64. Full STL designs for Dome, Body & Legs https://onedrive.live.com/redir?resid=E84CB8FD47152532!15273&authkey=!AGa5uWPtHTWmVno&ithint=folder%2c *Please note, work in progress. Just enabled tips to see what happens... Please feel free to send across a tiny tiny amount if you wish to! Not even sure if it works as I can't see anything on my screen :-). Here's a link to a superb build video by MightyJabba, great sdemonstration of the build and a beautiful finished model https://youtu.be/3WcUO5BmH0w Revised Radar Eye for accuracy (version2). Another brilliant build video from Trevor Fuller, check it out for reference. First thing Trevor has printed! https://youtu.be/KQ6VAYtlbDg. Please note, I've now finished a complete revision of all the models, version 2 (all shared freely and openly), check https://www.patreon.com/mrbaddeley for links.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Generally most pieces are designed to use need minimum or no support. Recommend at least 3 layers (or 4) to allow for sanding to a smooth finish.

comments.text: Hi, they'll fit a 200x200 bed and the a8 seems to be 220x 220 so should be fine. You'll have to print on the right orientation, not familiar with cura but most slicers have a 'place surface on bed' and rotate so sure it will work. It'll be a steep learning curve but it's also very rewarding when you get there. Filament wise, it's about 3 rolls for the dome (just over 2) and I'd guess between 7-9 for the body. It's modular so just print one piece at a time. Always use the Patreon files as they're most comprehensive and up to date.

comments.text: Have any of you seen this before?  It appears that once the pillars were reconnected at the top, the cooling/shrinking of the part caused the whole thing to cave in.  I'm printing ABS on a FlashForge Creator Pro at 230/110 and its fully enclosed so nice and hot in there.  Any idea what I can do to stop this?
comments.author: gspence

comments.text:
Hi there,
Yes I have seen similar. It's a problem with printing curved pieces stood up in abs. Basically I think the shrinkage on a curve causes the wall to move back or forth. Without the curve the effect is much less or virtually negated. I find the base adherence really makes a difference. I use abs and acetone to create a thin film on the bed and also use helper discs (thin discs at each corner). This works for me. I also use an enclosure.
comments.author: gspence

comments.text: Thanks for the response.  My printer is fully enclosed so the heat shouldn't be the issue.  The edges did curl up probably from the same problem.  I'm currently reprinting the piece in PLA to see how it compares to the green ABS print I linked.  I think PLA shrinks less, but I'd prefer the strength of ABS.   I'm also using a raft with the PLA version, which I didn't do in ABS.  There's a lot of time to invest printing these pieces so I just want to be sure I have my settings nailed down before I start.
comments.author: mrbaddeley

comments.text: Yeah, I guess PLA will be better (less shrinkage) but personally much prefer ABS for both strength and chemical welding with acetone. ABS shrinkage is worse on larger curved parts. First noticed if on a BB-8 I printed. The helper discs definitely improve things, the better overall base adherence the less 'wobble' you get on the wall.
comments.author: gspence

comments.text: Yeah, I may try one more ABS run with a raft.  So you'd rather acetone them together than use something like a plastic epoxy?  I feel like epoxy would fill gaps better and give a stronger hold unless you can really get a thick slurry of acetone and ABS.
comments.author: mrbaddeley

comments.text: Certainly do some tests but I've built over half dozen helmets, BB-8 and The full R2-D2 with chemical weld. When it's full set if you try to break it the plastic often goes before the joint.
comments.author: gspence

comments.text:
Hi there,
Yes I have seen similar. It's a problem with printing curved pieces stood up in abs. Basically I think the shrinkage on a curve causes the wall to move back or forth. Without the curve the effect is much less or virtually negated. I find the base adherence really makes a difference. I use abs and acetone to create a thin film on the bed and also use helper discs (thin discs at each corner). This works for me. I also use an enclosure.
comments.author: gspence

comments.text:
Hi there,
Yes I have seen similar. It's a problem with printing curved pieces stood up in abs. Basically I think the shrinkage on a curve causes the wall to move back or forth. Without the curve the effect is much less or virtually negated. I find the base adherence really makes a difference. I use abs and acetone to create a thin film on the bed and also use helper discs (thin discs at each corner). This works for me. I also use an enclosure.
comments.author: gspence

comments.text: Hi there, best way to check (and give you lots of points of measurement) is to open the 123d design file in 123d design. (Free download and the designs are linked in the dome description). In the software there's a measure tool (top right) which you can select any two points or faces and it shows the distance in mm or inches dependent on settings. This lets you check all the parts against the printed ones. I would also print a thin bar on the x axis, y axis (just short of bed size, maybe 150mm)and a 50mm high rectangle to check the x,y and z calibration. Even though it's a new printer and calibrated  on big prints it may be off, so worth checking.

comments.text:
LOL, no no no! Not a pro at all ; ) My little $600NZ Wanhao printer has me pulling my here out all the time. And yes not every print is successful. I guess I can afford to be blahzay as the ABS is cheap. I don't have a closure per say, but the unit dose sit in an open case cupboard so does create its own little eco system. I have had and still am having an awesome journey printing Mrbaddeley's R2D2 and have just a few bits and bobs to go. But I have several projects on as well to keep me occupied and the center foot has yet to be finalised. My 3D design skills are dismal so at this stage I'm relying on MrBaddeley to come up with an ingenious way where if possible R2's shoulders connect with a central rod to help with the leg flex and stability. I have 3 partly hand built static R2D2's in the garage originally inspired from Victor Franco and the guys at the R2D2's builders club (8 years in the making) 10 months ago I stumbled across 3D printing and MyBaddeleys incredible work on this project has been inspiring to say the least. I couldn't pass up on having an R2D2 do the 2 - 3 leg movement. It is actually this project where by I have learnt most of my skills in using ABS. One of the coolest things with ABS & Simplify3D is even if a print turns to custard and you are 20hours in on a 60hour print. I just pop out my calipers, measure the amount of good finished print, chuck the difference/ waste into my slurry jar. Deduct the difference (measuring distance) from the original print carry on printing. Slurry it together like every other piece and your all good ; )
Hey, if PLA is no different in price and it works for you, Great ; ) But by all means give ABS a go. you will appreciate some of the benefits it has to offer : ) and on occasion you will be as frustrated as beggary ; ) Good luck!
comments.author: mattnelson521

comments.text: ABS can warp and split and is not as easy to print with at times and is not organic like PLA, but I believe is stronger harder and lasts longer, is a breeze to glue together with the left over supports mixed in acetone. Bonds almost immediately, no waiting to glue the next piece in place and there is no extra cost in gluing material needed. PLA for me fluffs up when sanding, requires bondo or bog to finish and is more expensive $40.00 a roll compared to $4.00 a roll. ABS slurry can be brushed on and in most cases replaces a lot of filling and sanding and can give you a better smooth finish. PLA is difficuilt to get of the bed, where as ABS pops right off once the bed has cooled. There is no waste from ABS in the sense it is used again as slurry. For me ABS is definitely more economical on large prints cost wise and time wise. If I wanted to do a quick high resolution McDonalds toy, then I'd possibly use PLA ; )
comments.author: mattnelson521

comments.text: I'm with the OP. ABS just does not print well for me at all. I find I have to print parts 3 - 4 times out of ABS before I get a usable part (or I give up all together). Maybe, once I get my heat chamber finished, I'll be able to print ABS more reliably, but (with PLA) I load the model, hit print and walk away.

comments.author: Jace1969

comments.text:
Hi, yes it's a lazy susan mechanism. The frame has a half circle groove and the ring gear has a half circle groove which sits on top. I did try the printed ball bearings, they work but with quite a bit of "rumbling" as they're not perfect balls. I have since ordered some 10mm Steel Ball Bearings from ebay (very cheap) and added a little bearing grease / oil with a rather good effect, quite smooth and not too much noise.
So the dome sits on the gear, I've created a couple of plastic clips which firmly attached the dome to the gear (not uploaded yet, but will do). This means the dome is clipped to the gear, which rests on the frame holding the bearings. This still means that the dome and gear can be lifted off and the bearings are not held in place. My plan is the print two small gears, which attaches to a motor on one side and the other gear runs free on opposite sides of the frame. You will notice that the upper part of the ring gear has a bevelled edge, my plan is to create the small gear which is wider at the top, creating a lip which holds the ring gear in the frame. This will be on both sides of the frame (opposite), with the motor on one and the other free. Hope this all makes sense.
comments.author: Jace1969

comments.text: Hi do you have a diagram of how this is put together?
comments.author: video567

comments.text: Hi. I haven't but the parts are numbered. The lower ring (base) has the bracket to the bottom and the parts are printed with numbers on them (1-6), the upper ring sits on top of the lower (again printed numbers). The dome is in three "layers", the base layer is put together in order as they are numbered (files only are numbered). Inside are fins so you can match the second layer and finally the top pie section is glued in place. I used ABS with ABS "sludge" (Actetone & ABS mix) to glue together. The parts can be held together with Clothes Pegs. The Panels again are numbered in the files, starting the the front logic lights and working clockwise around. I used internet reference pictures for the painting and positioning. Some filling and sanding is obviously needed. then primer paint, main coat and I put a laquer on finally.

remixed_from.author: MSollack
remixed_from.title: Threadless Ball Screw. No More Backlash

title: Ball bearing nut for linear stepping motor.

description.text:
I designed the ball bearing nut for the linear screw of linear stepping motor.
It is a kind of derivative of Mark Sollack's threadless ball screw concept.
This is one of the concept design to prevent backlash on the linear stepping motor.
I did not test yet. but I hope it would be work properly.
The ball bearing nut was designed for quadruple-start 8mm lead length, 8pi linear screw.
The slope angle is 17.6568 deg.

The center height is 9 mm.
The thickness of the ball bearing nut is 12 mm.
The distance between the holes of the flange is 35 mm. BOM
  • Ball bearing nut ----------- 1 EA
  • 623zz ball bearing -------- 4 EA
  • M3x10 bolt ----------------- 4 EA
  • M3 nut ---------------------- 4 EA
  • M3 washer ----------------- 4 EA

comments.text: What about using a bearing with a flange, so that it sits deeper into the thread?
comments.author: Jupiter909

comments.text: Today I made this nut but with a few modifications. I added the ability to give some preload because 623 ball bearings appear to be loosy after few minutes of rolling. In any case there's a problem in this configuration: the nut tries to skip a row when under load, and there's a preferred direction where skidding is easier. Also I suppose the angle is not correct because the tendency to skip the rows is ciclycal even with no load on the nut. A double nut should work fine, I suppose 8 bearings are required also to remove the backlash (that now is present). I tested on my Replicator and the backlash was similar when using the original bronze nut. A parametric version to change preload and angle parameters would help a lot when looking for the best combination. Keep going!
comments.author: zebrauno

comments.text: Hi, zebrauno! You did the test! I tested this configuration just few days ago, I've been busy with other work. I found the same problems with you found on your test. So I used the two of ball bearing nut, please check out testing video on Youtube http://youtu.be/vhodLP9ws0Qhttp://youtu.be/vhodLP9ws0Q. And I agree with the angle is not appropriate. Thanks for comment!
comments.author: zebrauno

comments.text: looks great! just wondering what you used for your renderings.
comments.author: sergiotroiani

comments.text: I'm glad you like it! I'm using now Showcase 2014 for rendering. thanks! :)
comments.author: sergiotroiani

comments.text: How do you determine the angle at which the bearings are set? and how does it change with the pitch of the thread? Also would this work with a single start lead screw thread?
comments.author: danway60

comments.text:
Hi! Dan, the angle was determined as Arc Tangent ( 8 / 3.141592 * 8 ).
The model designed only for the 8mm lead, 8pi, 4-start thread, so it would not possible to apply to the other threads.
comments.author: danway60

comments.text: interesting, I'm curious why you have designed this for a linear screw thread. I can see it would give more "bite" but why ... did the previous smooth-rod version have problems like slipping, or repeatability issues (say after 100 times going back and forth it has err "positional drift"?) or are you just having a bit of fun here? cheers!!

comments.text: Thanks for good comment!  It just because of the simplicity of my printer, it's not because slipping or repeatabilty issues. The threadless ball screw system needs additional coupler and stopper than the linear stepping motor system. It would be a another option on my printer. :)
comments.author: charlie68

comments.text: Why 4 bearings?

comments.text: The linear screw has quadruple start thread, so it need the 4 bearings.
Ok, I see!

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

title: ROBO 3D Enclosure system with Y axis buffer tabs

description.text: Wanted to make a simple enclosure for my ROBO 3D to keep some of the heat in and drafts out. Originally built the tabs to help with some of the shutter when the Y is out and the X is doing smaller moves. Realized the tabs could be a mounting point and went from there. They are super-glued on..the blue tape is for fine adjustment. Got the plexi at Lowe's at $2.97 a sheet...8x10x.08 and based my brackets off that, no cutting is required. Everything is a piece that snaps together so no overhangs except on the rear tabs. The front panel slides up and out. I included a snip of the assembly for reference. It's actually pretty strong, my hand has bounced off the front a few times reaching for a part, forgetting it's there...Haven't done the back but believe it to be a mirror image of the front...

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

No

200

.10

When I extracted the parts they were microscopic. the thing would have been about 1 inch wide if it had been printed. can you provide either the actual dimensions for the 2 front parts or so I can figure the multiplier to for the rest of the parts. I want to get one of these going for my printer.
Thanks
comments.author: boomer46

comments.text: If you're using MC try scaling it to 10 (that's what I have to do each time I import anything I designed), orient on table so no overhangs, save and print.  For reference, the outer connecting corners are approx 1"x.75"x.75".  Anything else lmk....D
comments.author: boomer46

comments.text: I currently have a box made of insulation covering my robo while printing, works pretty well since I print in a cool basement.  Huge improvement in my prints.  This looks like a great solution, and much nicer than what I am currently using do you know how well it raises the temp inside the box?
comments.author: Neotorin

comments.text: Well, you sparked my curiosity so I ran some temperature numbers.  Printing PLA with a bed temp of 45 and extruder at 200...temp inside case was measured at 85f at about 5" up off the build plate just rear of the extruder carriage.  Ambient room temp was 66f, so about a 20* gain.  This was with both sides enclosed...
comments.author: Neotorin

comments.text: To be honest I'm not exactly sure the temp increase, it's there though.  It's most noticeable when printing ABS with the hotter settings, the panels get a little warm to the touch, so I know it's keeping some in, although this stuff probably really isn't that great at insulating in general.  But, it does keep the drafts out to make some stagnant air inside, and it's nice to see whats going on inside.  I had actually thought about using a foam board (thicker so different dimensioned parts) for the backside as an alternative that would probably keep the heat in better, a couple of plugs on the sides of spool holder would probably help too...
comments.author: Neotorin

description.text:
Finished bearing size of 17 mm wide x 78 mm with 7 rollers. I tried to make this build a snug fit. Your printer/filament may give you different results. I found that the same part will be slightly different in size when color was changed. Part sizes given will not usually print that size.

Printer: Check bed/nozzle clearance. The 1st filament layer should be same as rest to try and get square edges.

Cleanup: Remove ridges on vertical edges, chamfer holes and flat sand components. A finger/finger nail will help.

Bearing Rollers;
String them on a 7/32 drill bit by hand (pliers). Spin the bit while holding file/sand paper to the rollers. Round is good. Next, Spin the bit while holding the outer most roller with the pliers to clean the inside hole and remove one at a time.
The rollers can be reloaded on the bit and held into place with a discarded roller that has been heated in water and formed around the bit. A #1 drill bit will give .2 mm larger hole. Scale as necessary.

Bearing sides;
Slow print speed to around 25% when starting the pins. A timer will work as a reminder.

Check the mating surfaces. Work with the parts until the desired fit is achieved.

Insert the bearing pin side into the collar a little past flush. Load the rollers. Check the fit up by inserting a piece of 3/4" PVC. Then rotate the bearing hole side until the flat sides of the circle & pins line up. Press together.

That's the bearing part. You may stack as many together is you like. There are two options for the inside spacer when stacking more then two. You can use one with rollers.

Everything should move easily. Apply lub & glue if desired.

Pulley sides: I provided these to use bearing as a filament guide spool.

Some images show the components (colors do not match) required to make the completed part below.

3.10.16 Added low resistance rollerV2. Design per image.
3.12.16 Added larger dia. side pulley & inside race bushing for 1/2" bolt. Used a 1/2" bit for internal cleanup. Cut 3/4" PVC to appropriate length. A lathe will dial things in.

I would be interested in how the bearing is used.

description.text:
This is a handy tool used to make little paper pots out of newspaper. Great for starting seeds, and easy to use.

I saw some things designed to make newspaper pots, but none of them were quite what I had in mind (either requiring supports, too complicated, no grips, etc) so I decided to design my own. Editing the .scad file allows you to easily change the size of the pot, depth, grip sizes, etc.

Just cut a strip of newspaper (use black and white because colored ink can contain toxins--black ink is mostly soy) around hand-width. Then, wrap it around the cylinder on the larger tool part. Fold the ends in, press it into the cap, and carefully remove the newly-formed pot! The black and white newspaper is also biodegradable, so once the plants are ready to go in the ground you can just drop the entire thing in.

Clarification: This is actually being released under the MIT License, available at https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT. Thingiverse did not give this as an option but I want to share it anyway. You can pretty much do anything you want with it!
